Panels

Panel components is a substantial piece of our UI that contains several other components such as tables, segmented navigation, graphs and other elements where the user needs to interact within the space of a panel.

Sub components of the panel

The panel is divided primarily of panel__header, panel__body and panel__footeras demonstrated in the following example:

Example

Header

Body: This is where you'll find the main content of the panel
Footer: Here you'll find ancilary action to the panel, such us pagination. 

<div class="panel">
  <div class="panel__header">
    <h3>Header</h3>
  </div>
  <div class="panel__body">
    Body: This is where you'll find the main content of the panel
  </div>
  <div class="panel__footer">
    Footer: Here you'll find ancilary action to the panel, such us pagination.
  </div>
</div>

The panel component should allow you to structure it in a flexible way. For instance you can render the panel simply with a panel__body should you not need panel__header or panel__footer. It should alwasy have a body, though. Most commonly you might not need the panel__footer as this is mostly used when the panel is used in the Modal component.

The panel__header always should have an h3 to wrap its title.

Panel with table inside

When including a table in a panel, you would need to include the panel__body--with-table class to remove the default padding.

Example

Panel with back navigation

Panel might load content and transition into a different level.

Example

Users

Line of text

Line of text


<div class="panel">
  <div class="panel__header">
    <div class="panel__actions-item">

Panel with spinners

Panels might have spinners in two place:

  • In the header
  • In the body

In the header

Example

Fleet(45)

Line of text

Line of text


<div class="panel">
  <div class="panel__header">
    <div class="panel__title">
      <h3>Fleet(45)</h3>
    </div>
    <div class="panel__actions-item">
      <div class="spinner spinner__small spinner__small--default"></div>
    </div>
  </div>
  <div class="panel__body">
    <p>Line of text</p>
    <p>Line of text</p>
  </div>
</div>

In the body

Example

Fleet(45)


<div class="panel">
  <div class="panel__header">
    <h3>Fleet(45)</h3>
  </div>
  <div class="panel__body panel__body--with-loader" style="min-height: 200px;">
    <div class="spinner spinner__small-cover spinner__small-cover--default"></div>
  </div>
</div>

Panel with actionable buttons on header

We will run into scenarios where we need to contain actions or behaviours within the panels such us expand/collaps the panel, include specific settings and even export/import into them. Here is an example that would allow great flexibility depending of the needs of panels.

Example

Visualizations

Visualization graphic 2

Actionable buttons triggering a contextual menu

Panel with no styles

Panels are the core component of the chunk of content you'll be using on our apps. Those could be tables, lists, graphs, etc. There will be circumstances where you won't want to to show panels as panels but rather as simply chunks of content. Structurally they are composed of the same elements, but slightly different depending of the context.

Example

Loans tool

Visualization graphic 1
Visualization graphic 2

Panel with header buttons

There might be scenarios where you'd need to have buttons in the header. Example could be a set of segmented navigation or tab navigation or if you need to send form information.

Example

Cashflows

SettingsActivityTrends
Visualization graphic 1
Visualization graphic 2

      <a class="btn btn__neutral btn__neutral--outline btn__size-s" href="#">Trends</a>
    </div>
  </div>

      <div class="grid__item">

          Visualization graphic 1
